member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeAcquisitionType
member.summary: Specifies how the digitizer acquires data and fills the waveform record.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeAcquisitionType.Normal
member.summary: The normal resolution mode of the digitizer.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeAcquisitionType.FlexibleResolution
member.summary: The flexible resolution mode of the digitizer. This value may not be supported on all devices.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeAcquisitionType.Ddc
member.summary: The DDC mode of the NI 5620/5621 digitizer.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeCalibrationUtility
member.summary: Represents the NI-SCOPE calibration utility.

remarks.para: For more information, refer to the Calibration topics in the NI-SCOPE Function Reference Help.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeCalibrationUtility.DeviceTemperature
member.summary: Gets the temperature of the instrument in degrees Celsius from the onboard sensor.
member.value: The temperature of the instrument in degrees Celsius from the onboard sensor.
member.seealso: Mapping the NI-SCOPE .NET API to the NI-SCOPE C API

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelDdc
member.summary: Defines the properties related to the digital down converter (DDC) block in a high speed digitizer.
member.remarks:
You can only query or set the properties of this class when the scope session is associated with an instrument that supports onboard signal processing (OSP).
You can use the DDC block of the NI 5142 for the following applications:
Alias-Protected Decimation: For alias-protected decimation applications, complete the following steps:
Set DDC to .
Set to .
Set to the desired decimated sample rate.
Set to .
AM Demodulation: For AM demodulation applications, complete the following steps:
Set DDC to .
Set to .
Set to the desired baseband sample rate.
Set to .
Set to the carrier frequency of the AM signal you want to downconvert.
Quadrature Downconversion: For quadrature downconversion applications, complete the following steps:
Set DDC to .
Set to .
Set to the desired IQ data rate.
Set to .
Set to the desired center frequency of the IF band you want to downconvert.
Baseband Decimation: For baseband decimation applications, complete the following steps:
Set DDC to .
Set to .
Set to the desired baseband sample rate.
Set to .
Set to channel "1."
To use the NI 5142 in normal digitizer mode, set to .

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelDdc.Enabled
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the digital down converter (DDC) block of the digitizer is enabled.
member.remarks:
if you need to use any of the onboard signal processing (OSP) functionality of your OSP-enabled instrument, or , to disable all other DDC-related properties and have no effect on the acquired signal.
You can access this property only with high-speed digitizers that support onboard signal processing (OSP), such as the NI 5142. If you open a session with an instrument that does not support OSP and you attempt to access this property, a is thrown.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelDdc.CenterFrequency
member.summary: Gets or sets the frequency, in hetrz, at which the DDC block frequency translates the input data. This frequency is the region of the spectrum that you want to downconvert to baseband.
member.remarks: You can access this property only with high-speed digitizers that support onboard signal processing (OSP), such as the NI 5142. If you open a session with an instrument that does not support OSP and you attempt to access this property, a exception is thrown.
member.value: The default value is 10 MHz. The valid value range is 0 to (0.5 × for digitizer).

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelDdc.QSource
member.summary: Gets or sets the channel that is the input to the Q data stream of the digital downconverter (DDC).
member.value: The default value is the channel that the property is registered to. All valid channels for the instrument are valid values.
member.remarks: You can access this property only with high-speed digitizers that support onboard signal processing (OSP), such as the NI 5142. If you open a session with an instrument that does not support OSP and you attempt to access this property, a is thrown.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelDdc.FrequencyTranslationEnabled
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the frequency translation of the data around the selected center frequency down to baseband is enabled.
member.remarks: You can access this property only with high-speed digitizers that support onboard signal processing (OSP), such as the NI 5142. If you open a session with an instrument that does not support OSP and you attempt to access this property, a is thrown.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelDdc.FrequencyTranslationPhaseI
member.summary: Gets or sets the I oscillator phase in degrees at the first point acquired.
member.value: The default value is 0. Valid values are -360 to 360, inclusive.
member.remarks: You can access this property only with high-speed digitizers that support onboard signal processing (OSP), such as the NI 5142. If you open a session with an instrument that does not support OSP and you attempt to access this property, a is thrown.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelDdc.FrequencyTranslationPhaseQ
member.summary: Gets or sets the Q oscillator phase in degrees at the first point acquired.
member.value: The default value is 90. Valid values are -360 to 360, inclusive.
member.remarks: You can access this property only with high-speed digitizers that support onboard signal processing (OSP), such as the NI 5142. If you open a session with an instrument that does not support OSP and you attempt to access this property, a is thrown.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelMeasurement
member.summary: Represents the sub-objects that contain properties to allow you to configure the digitizers to obtain scalar and array measurements.
member.remarks: For more information, refer to Making Waveform Measurements in the NI High-Speed Digitizers Help or to the Scalar Measurements and Array Measurements topics in the NI-SCOPE Function Reference Help.
member.seealso: Mapping the NI-SCOPE .NET API to the NI-SCOPE C API

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelMeasurement.Filter
member.summary: Gets measurement properties related to filtering.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelMeasurement.ReferenceLevel
member.summary: Gets properties related to different reference levels.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelMeasurement.TimeHistogram
member.summary: Gets properties that are related to time histogram measurements.
member.seealso: Mapping the NI-SCOPE .NET API to the NI-SCOPE C API

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelMeasurement.VoltageHistogram
member.summary: Gets properties that are related to voltage histogram measurements.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelMeasurement.ArrayGain
member.summary: Gets or sets a scalar value that is multiplied by every element of an array during the Array Gain measurement.
member.seealso: Mapping the NI-SCOPE .NET API to the NI-SCOPE C API

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelMeasurement.ArrayOffset
member.summary: Gets or sets a scalar value that is added to every element of an array during the Array Offset measurement.
member.seealso: Mapping the NI-SCOPE .NET API to the NI-SCOPE C API

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelMeasurement.HysteresisPercent
member.summary: Gets or sets the percentage of the full-scale vertical range for the hysteresis window size. Digital hysteresis is used in several scalar waveform measurements.
member.seealso: Mapping the NI-SCOPE .NET API to the NI-SCOPE C API

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelMeasurement.InterpolationSamplingFactor
member.summary: Gets or sets, indirectly, the new number of points for polynomial interpolation measurements. The new number of points is the input number of points times the sampling factor.
member.seealso: Mapping the NI-SCOPE .NET API to the NI-SCOPE C API

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelMeasurement.LastHistogramSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of bins in the last acquisition histogram. This histogram is used to determine several scalar measurements, such as voltage low and voltage high.
member.seealso: Mapping the NI-SCOPE .NET API to the NI-SCOPE C API

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelMeasurement.OtherChannel
member.summary: Gets or sets the second channel for two-channel measurements. If processing steps are registered with this channel, the processing is done before the waveform is used in a two-channel measurement.
member.seealso: Mapping the NI-SCOPE .NET API to the NI-SCOPE C API

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelMeasurement.PolynomialInterpolationOrder
member.summary: Gets or sets the polynomial order used for the polynomial interpolation measurement. For example, an order of 1 specifies linear interpolation whereas an order of 2 specifies parabolic interpolation. Any positive integer is valid.
member.seealso: Mapping the NI-SCOPE .NET API to the NI-SCOPE C API

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelMeasurement.AddWaveformProcessing(NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeArrayMeasurementType)
member.summary: Adds one measurement to the list of processing steps that are completed before the measurement.
member.param: The array measurement to add.
member.remarks: The processing is added on a per-channel basis, and the processing measurements are completed in the same order in which they are registered. The channel list considered is the channel associated with this measurement object. All measurement library properties (properties present in and its sub-objects) are cached at the time of registering the processing, and this set of parameters is used during the processing step. The processing measurements are streamed, so the result of the first processing step is used as the input for the next step. The processing is done before any other measurements.
member.seealso: Mapping the NI-SCOPE .NET API to the NI-SCOPE C API

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelMeasurement.ClearWaveformProcessing
member.summary: Clears the list of processing steps assigned to the given channel.
member.remarks: The processing steps are added with .
member.seealso: Mapping the NI-SCOPE .NET API to the NI-SCOPE C API

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelMeasurement.ClearWaveformMeasurements
member.summary: Clears the waveform statistics on the channel and for all measurements.
member.remarks: Every time a measurement is called, the statistics information is updated, including the min, max, mean, standard deviation, and number of updates.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelMeasurement.ClearWaveformMeasurements(NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType)
member.summary: Clears the waveform statistics on the channel and for scalar measurements.
member.param: The scalar measurement to clear the statistics for.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelMeasurement.ClearWaveformMeasurements(NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeArrayMeasurementType)
member.summary: Clears the waveform statistics on the channel and for scalar measurements.
member.param: The array measurement to clear the statistics for.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelMeasurement.Read(NationalInstruments.PrecisionTimeSpan,System.Int64,NationalInstruments.AnalogWaveformCollection{System.Double})
member.summary: Initiates an acquisition, waits for it to complete, and retrieves the data.This method may return multiple waveforms depending on the number of channels, the acquisition type, and the number of records you specify.
member.param: The time to wait for data to be acquired. Using 0 for this parameter tells NI-SCOPE to fetch whatever is currently available. Using -1 for this parameter implies infinite timeout.

The maximum number of samples to fetch for each waveform. If the acquisition finishes with fewer points than requested, some instruments return partial data if the acquisition finished, was aborted, or a timeout of 0 was used. Use –1 for this parameter if you want to fetch all available samples. The method reads the actual record length and attempts to acquire all available samples. If it fails to complete within the timeout period, the method returns an error.

The waveform object whose memory can be reused while creating the output waveform. To allocate memory during the call to this method, set to . The method will also allocate memory during the call if is set to a waveform object with zero-sized data or is set to a waveform object with a different size than that required for the output waveform. For example, if is set to a waveform object with the same size as that required for this method call, then no new memory is allocated for the output waveform, and instead the memory of the waveform object from will be reused for the output waveform.
member.returns:
An object of type . NI-SCOPE returns this data sequentially, so all record 0 waveforms are first. For example, with a channel list of 0,1, you would have the following index values:
index 0 = record 0, channel 0
index x = record 0, channel 1
index 2x = record 1, channel 0
index 3x = record 1, channel 1
Where x = the record length
If you are using this entry point or any of its overloads or async versions to read complex data, then you will either recieve double the number of samples or double the number of records requested depending on the value of .
If is set to , then the waveforms returned will contain twice the number of samples specified by . Every two samples represents interleaved IQ data.
If is set to , then the waveform collection returned will contain twice the number of records requested. Each pair of records represents one waveform of I data, and one waveform of Q data.
member.exception:
was called after the associated
or
object was disposed.
The underlying NI-SCOPE driver returned an error.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelMeasurement.BeginFetchInt32(NationalInstruments.PrecisionTimeSpan,System.Int64,NationalInstruments.AnalogWaveformCollection{System.Int32},System.AsyncCallback,System.Object)
member.summary: Begins an asynchronous retrieval of data from a previously initiated acquisition. Refer to Using Fetch Functions for more information on using this method.
member.remarks: Some functionality, such as time stamping, is not supported in all digitizers. Refer to Features Supported by Device for more information.
member.param: The time to wait for data to be acquired. Using 0 for this parameter tells NI-SCOPE to fetch whatever is currently available. Using for this parameter implies infinite timeout.

The maximum number of samples to fetch for each waveform. If the acquisition finishes with fewer points than requested, some instruments return partial data if the acquisition finished, was aborted, or a timeout of 0 was used. Use –1 for this parameter if you want to fetch all available samples. The method reads the actual record length and attempts to acquire all available samples. If it fails to complete within the timeout period, the method throws an exception.

The waveform object whose memory can be reused while creating the output waveform. To allocate memory during the call to this method, set to . The method will also allocate memory during the call if is set to a waveform object with zero-sized data or is set to a waveform object with a different size than that required for the output waveform. For example, if is set to a waveform object with the same size as that required for this method call, then no new memory is allocated for the output waveform, and instead the memory of the waveform object from will be reused for the output waveform.
A delegate of type , which will be invoked once the operation is complete.
The state of the asynchronous operation.
member.returns: An that represents the pending asynchronous fetch.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelMeasurement.EndFetchInt32(System.IAsyncResult)
member.summary: Waits for a pending asynchronous fetch to complete.
member.param: An that represents the asynchronous fetch, which could still be pending.
member.returns: An object of type . NI-SCOPE returns this data sequentially, so all record 0 waveforms are first. For example, with a channel list of 0,1, you would have the following index values: index 0 = record 0, channel 0 index x = record 0, channel 1 index 2x = record 1, channel 0 index 3x = record 1, channel 1 Where x = the record length

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelMeasurement.FetchDouble(NationalInstruments.PrecisionTimeSpan,System.Int64,NationalInstruments.AnalogWaveformCollection{System.Double})
member.summary: Returns the waveform from a previously initiated acquisition that the digitizer acquires for the specified channel. This method returns scaled voltage waveforms. Refer to Using Fetch Functions for more information on using this method.
member.remarks: Some functionality, such as time stamping, is not supported in all digitizers. Refer to Features Supported by Device for more information.
member.param: The time to wait for data to be acquired. Using 0 for this parameter tells NI-SCOPE to fetch whatever is currently available. Using -1 for this parameter implies infinite timeout.

The maximum number of samples to fetch for each waveform. If the acquisition finishes with fewer points than requested, some instruments return partial data if the acquisition finished, was aborted, or a timeout of 0 was used. Use –1 for this parameter if you want to fetch all available samples. The method reads the actual record length and attempts to acquire all available samples. If it fails to complete within the timeout period, the method returns an error.

The waveform object whose memory can be reused while creating the output waveform. To allocate memory during the call to this method, set to . The method will also allocate memory during the call if is set to a waveform object with zero-sized data or is set to a waveform object with a different size than that required for the output waveform. For example, if is set to a waveform object with the same size as that required for this method call, then no new memory is allocated for the output waveform, and instead the memory of the waveform object from will be reused for the output waveform.
member.returns:
An object of type . NI-SCOPE returns this data sequentially, so all record 0 waveforms are first. For example, with a channel list of 0,1, you would have the following index values:
index 0 = record 0, channel 0
index x = record 0, channel 1
index 2x = record 1, channel 0
index 3x = record 1, channel 1
Where x = the record length
If you are using this entry point or any of its overloads or async versions to read complex data, then you will either recieve double the number of samples or double the number of records requested depending on the value of .
If is set to , then the waveforms returned will contain twice the number of samples specified by . Every two samples represents interleaved IQ data.
If is set to , then the waveform collection returned will contain twice the number of records requested. Each pair of records represents one waveform of I data, and one waveform of Q data.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelMeasurementFilter.CenterFrequency
member.summary: Gets or sets the center frequency, in hertz, for bandpass and bandstop filters. The width of the filter is specified by , where the cutoff frequencies are the center width.
member.seealso: Mapping the NI-SCOPE .NET API to the NI-SCOPE C API

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelMeasurementFilter.CutoffFrequency
member.summary: Gets or sets the cutoff frequency, in hertz, for lowpass and highpass filters. The cutoff frequency definition varies depending on the filter.
member.seealso: Mapping the NI-SCOPE .NET API to the NI-SCOPE C API

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelMeasurementFilter.FirFilterWindow
member.summary: Gets or sets the FIR window type. The symmetric windows are applied to the FIR filter coefficients to limit passband ripple in FIR filters.
member.value: Specifies the . The default value is .
member.seealso: Mapping the NI-SCOPE .NET API to the NI-SCOPE C API

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelOnboardSignalProcessing
member.summary: Provides methods and properties for configuring the Onboard Signal Processing (OSP) components of high speed digitizers.
member.remarks:
This property can be used only with high-speed digitizers that support onboard signal processing (OSP). is thrown when this property is accessed or any of the sub-properties are set or accessed on an instrument that does not provide OSP. The main components of the Onboard Signal Processing block include the following:
Digital Down-Converter -
The DDC takes a programmable portion of the Nyquist_Theorem spectrum of the ADC and moves it down to baseband (centered around 0 Hz). This process is performed by first frequency translating the center of the band of interest to 0 Hz. The data is then filtered and decimated to get alias-protected data of the requested bandwidth. The data output from the DDC is stored into memory at this lower sample rate as complex IQ pairs.
Filtering And Decimation -
The filtering and decimation stage of the OSP block reduces the effective sample rate of the digitizer while protecting the frequency spectrum of the decimated data from aliases. This protection occurs when the data passes through a lowpass filter before decimation. The normal decimation in digitizers (when not using OSP) does not protect the frequency spectrum of the decimated data from aliases.
Digital Gain -
Digital gain can be used to change the gain of each channel. You can program the digital gain of each channel independently using the . The gain can range from –1.5 to +1.5 (unitless). You can use the digital gain to attenuate the channel data to eliminate overflows in the OSP block.
Digital Offset -
The digital offset can be used to change the offset of each channel. You can program the digital offset of each channel independently using the .
Frequency Translation -
Frequency translation moves the Nyquist Theorem frequency spectrum of the acquired signal by the amount specified by the . This is accomplished by multiplying the acquired data stream with the output of the numerically controlled oscillator (NCO). The NCO is a digital circuit that creates two sine waves of the same frequency (the Center Frequency) with two independent phases. You can use the CenterFrequency to set the carrier frequency. The I phase cosine waveform is multiplied by the I signal path, and the Q phase cosine waveform is multiplied by the Q data path. The I and Q phases are programmable from 0° to 360° by setting the and properties. Both the frequency and the phases can be updated during acquisition. The NCO outputs start at the specified phase values when the start trigger is received.
Data Processing Mode -
The Data Processing Mode Selection stage selects between and processing. In Real mode, only the Real I data is returned when a waveform fetch is executed. In Complex mode, the I and Q data streams are interleaved before they are stored to memory. When the complex data is fetched, the data is returned as interleaved I and Q data. The data can be fetched as an array of complex IQ samples, as an array of interleaved real I and Q samples, or as separate arrays of real I and Q samples.
Additional properties are available for instruments that support OSP. You access these properties, and , from the class. and are not channel specific.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeMeasurement
member.summary: Represents the sub-objects that contain the properties and methods related to acquisition.
member.remarks: For more information, refer to the Acquisition Functions topic in the NI High Speed Digitizers Help or to the Fetch and Read topics in the NI-SCOPE Function Reference Help.
member.seealso: Mapping the NI-SCOPE .NET API to the NI-SCOPE C API

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeMeasurement.Initiate
member.summary: Initiates a waveform acquisition.
member.remarks: After you call this method, the digitizer leaves the Idle state and waits for a trigger. The digitizer acquires a waveform for each enabled channel.
member.seealso: Mapping the NI-SCOPE .NET API to the NI-SCOPE C API

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeMeasurement.Abort
member.summary: Aborts an acquisition and returns the digitizer to the Idle state. Call this method if the digitizer times out waiting for a trigger.
member.seealso: Mapping the NI-SCOPE .NET API to the NI-SCOPE C API

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeMeasurement.Status
member.summary: Gets the status information about the acquisition.
member.seealso: Mapping the NI-SCOPE .NET API to the NI-SCOPE C API
member.returns: Returns .

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeMeasurement.RisInAutoSetupAllowed
member.summary: Specifies whether the digitizer should use RIS sample rates when searching for a frequency in autosetup.
member.value: Value indicating whether the digitizer should use RIS sample rates when searching for a frequency in autosetup.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeMeasurement.AutoSetup
member.summary: Automatically configures the instrument. When this method is called, the digitizer senses the input signal and automatically configures many of the instrument settings. If a signal is detected on a channel, the driver chooses the smallest available vertical range that is larger than the signal range.
member.remarks: If no signal is found on any analog input channel, a warning is returned, and all channels are enabled. A channel is considered to have a signal present if the signal is at least 10% of the smallest vertical range available for that channel.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeMeasurement.PointsDone
member.summary: Gets the actual number of samples acquired since the last fetch, relative to the configured value for FetchRelativeTo, including FetchOffset and for the current configured RecordNumberToFetch.
member.value: Actual number of samples acquired since the last fetch.
member.seealso: Mapping the NI-SCOPE .NET API to the NI-SCOPE C API

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeMeasurement.RecordsDone
member.summary: Gets the number of records that have been completely acquired.
member.value: Number of records that have been completely acquired.
member.seealso: Mapping the NI-SCOPE .NET API to the NI-SCOPE C API

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeMeasurement.Commit
member.summary: Commits to hardware all the parameter settings associated with the task.
member.remarks: Use this method if you want a parameter change to be immediately reflected in the hardware. This method is not supported for Traditional NI-DAQ (Legacy) instruments.
member.seealso: Mapping the NI-SCOPE .NET API to the NI-SCOPE C API

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeMeasurement.FetchInterleavedData
member.summary: Gets or sets a value specifying whether to retrieve one array with alternating values on the NI 5620/5621.
member.value: , to retrieve one array with alternating values on the NI 5620/5621; otherwise, .
member.remarks: You can use this attribute to retrieve a single array with I and Q interleaved instead of two separate arrays. If set to , the resulting array is twice the size of the actual record length.
member.exception:
was accessed after the associated
or object was disposed.
The underlying NI-SCOPE driver returned an error.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeMeasurement.FetchInterleavedIQData
member.summary: Specifies whether a fetch call retrieves a single waveform with I and Q interleaved, or two separate waveforms.
member.value: , if the number of elements returned by scalar fetch types (such as 16-bit integer) is twice the requested number of samples, and if during DDC acquisitions in Complex mode, two noninterleaved arrays of data are returned per channel, per record. The default value is .
member.remarks:
This attribute can be used only with high-speed digitizers that support onboard signal processing (OSP). NI-SCOPE throws an exception if you use this attribute with an instrument that does not support OSP.
If this is set to , then the following methods, as well as their overloads and async versions, will return waveforms with twice the number of samples specified: , , , , and .

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeMeasurement.FetchRelativeTo
member.summary: Gets or sets the position to start fetching within one record.
member.value: The default value of this property is instrument-dependent. Valid values are , , , , and .

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeMeasurement.FetchOffset
member.summary: Specifies the offset, in samples, to start fetching data within each record. The offset is applied relative to . The offset can be positive or negative.
member.value: The default value of this property is instrument-dependent.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeDriverOperation.Cache
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to cache the value of properties.
member.value: if caching is enabled; otherwise, . The default value is .
member.remarks: If you set this property to , NI-SCOPE tracks the current NI-SCOPE instrument settings and avoids sending redundant commands to the instrument. NI-SCOPE can either always cache or never cache particular properties, regardless of the setting of this property.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeDriverOperation.InvalidateAllAttributes
member.summary: Invalidates all properties.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeDriverOperation.RangeCheck
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to validate property values and method parameters. If you enable this property, NI-SCOPE validates the parameter values that you pass to NI-SCOPE methods.
member.value: if validating property values and method parameters are enabled; otherwise, .
member.remarks: Range-checking parameters are very useful for debugging. After you validate your program, you can set this property to to disable range checking and maximize performance.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeDriverOperation.QueryInstrumentStatus
member.summary: Gets or sets whether NI-SCOPE queries the instrument status after each operation. NI-SCOPE can choose to ignore status checking for particular properties, regardless of the setting of this property.
member.remarks:
NI-SCOPE can choose to ignore status checking for particular properties, regardless of the setting of this property.
Querying the instrument status is useful for debugging. After you validate your program, you can set this property to to disable status checking and maximize performance.

if interchangeability checking is enabled; otherwise .

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeDriverOperation.LogicalName
member.summary: Gets the logical name that you specified when opening the current session.
member.value: A representing the logical name that you specified when opening the current IVI session.
member.remarks: You may pass a logical name to the NI-SCOPE session during initialization of session. The IVI configuration utility must contain an entry for the logical name. The logical name entry refers to a driver session section in the IVI configuration file. The driver session section specifies a physical instrument and initial options.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeDriverOperation.IOResourceDescriptor
member.summary: Gets the resource name that the NI-SCOPE uses to identify the physical instrument.
member.value: A representing the resource descriptor that you specified for the physical instrument.
member.remarks: If you initialize NI-SCOPE with a logical name, this property contains the resource name that corresponds to the entry in the IVI configuration utility. If you initialize NI-SCOPE with the resource name, this property contains that value.

if events and callbacks are invoked through the or ; otherwise, events and callbacks are invoked directly.

member.seealso: Events, Callbacks, and Thread Safety in Measurement Studio .NET Class Libraries

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeDriverOperation.Dispose
member.summary: Closes the specified session and deallocates the reserved resources, if not already disposed.
member.remarks:
You can call this method safely more than once, even if the session is already closed.
A call to this method disposes the SafeHandle class used to hold the instrument handle. If the call to this method fails due to some reason, such as the session being closed by some external means, you will not be notified about the failure. To help you identify failures in the ReleaseHandle method of the SafeHandle class, managed debugging assistant (MDA) is activated.
For details, refer to .
The call to this method fails when you externally close a session by:
Initializing a session with a resource name for which the session is already open, within the same process. This causes the instrument handle held by the existing session to become invalid.
Getting the instrument handle out using and closing this handle directly.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeTrigger.TdcEnabled
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the digitizer should record the trigger position precisely using time-digital conversion (TDC).
member.value: Gets or sets whether the digitizer should record the trigger position precisely using TDC.
member.remarks: Disabling TDC by setting this property to may reduce rearm time but causes the digitizer to round the trigger position to the nearest sample clock.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeTrigger.StartToReferenceTriggerHoldoff
member.summary: Gets or sets the length of time, in seconds, you want the digitizer to wait after it starts acquiring data until the digitizer enables the trigger system to detect a Reference Stop trigger.
member.value: Valid values for this property are instrument-dependent, and range from 0.0 seconds to 171.8 seconds.
member.seealso: Mapping the NI-SCOPE .NET API to the NI-SCOPE C API

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeTrigger.IsAutoTriggered
member.summary: Gets whether the acquisition was auto triggered.
member.value: Auto triggering occurs if the is set to , and no trigger has been received for a certain amount of time. , if the acquisition is triggered in this scenario and , if the acquisition is not triggered.
member.seealso: Mapping the NI-SCOPE .NET API to the NI-SCOPE C API

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeTrigger.EdgeTrigger

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeTrigger.Holdoff
member.summary: Gets or sets the length of time, in seconds, the digitizer waits after detecting a trigger before enabling the trigger subsystem to detect another trigger.
member.value: Valid values for this property are instrument-dependent, and range from 0.0 seconds to 171.8 seconds.
member.remarks: This property affects instrument operation only when the digitizer requires multiple acquisitions to build a complete waveform. The digitizer requires multiple waveform acquisitions when it uses equivalent-time sampling or when the digitizer is configured for a multirecord acquisition through the property .
member.seealso: Mapping the NI-SCOPE .NET API to the NI-SCOPE C API

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeTrigger.EndOfRecordToAdvanceTriggerHoldoff
member.summary: Gets or sets the adjustable period of time between records that allows for fetching data from the digitizer during a multi-record acquisition.
member.value: The adjustable period of time between records that allows for fetching data from the digitizer during a multi-record acquisition.
member.remarks: This attribute disables sampling and triggering.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeTrigger.Type
member.summary: Get or sets the type of the trigger in use.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeTrigger.Level
member.summary: Gets or sets the voltage threshold, in volts, for the trigger subsystem.
member.value:
The values of the properties and determine the valid range for the trigger level on the channel used as the Trigger Source. The value passed for the parameter must meet the following conditions:
Trigger Level <= (Range/2) + Offset
Range >= (-Range/2) + Offset
member.remarks: This property affects instrument behavior only when the is set to , , or .

member.summary: Configures the common properties for video triggering, including the signal format, TV event, line number, polarity, and enable DC restore. A video trigger occurs when the digitizer finds a valid video signal sync. When you initiate an acquisition, the digitizer waits for the start trigger, which is configured through the attribute. The default is . Upon receiving the start trigger the digitizer begins sampling pretrigger points. After the digitizer finishes sampling pretrigger points, the digitizer waits for a reference (stop) trigger that you specify with a method such as this one. Upon receiving the reference trigger the digitizer finishes the acquisition after completing posttrigger sampling. With each Configure Trigger method, you specify configuration parameters such as the trigger source and the amount of trigger delay.
member.param: The trigger source. Refer to for defined values.

Offsets each video line so the clamping level (the portion of the video line between the end of the color burst and the beginning of the active image) is moved to zero volt. Refer to for defined values.
The type of video signal sync the digitizer should look for. Refer to for more information.
The TV event you want to trigger on. You can trigger on a specific or on the next coming line or field of the signal.

The line number to trigger on. The line number range covers an entire frame and is referenced as shown on Vertical Blanking and Synchronization Signal. Refer to for more information. Default value is 1
The polarity of the video signal sync.
Applies coupling and filtering options to the trigger signal. Refer to for more information.
The length of time the digitizer waits after detecting a trigger before enabling NI-SCOPE to detect another trigger. Refer to for more information.
The amount of time the digitizer waits after receiving the trigger to start acquiring data. Refer to for more information.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeDriverUtility.Reset
member.summary: Resets all properties to their default value and stops export of all external signals and events.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeDriverUtility.ResetDevice
member.summary: Performs a hard reset on the instrument.
member.remarks: Resets the instrument to a known state. The method disables power generation, resets session properties to their default values, properties clears errors such as overtemperature and unexpected loss of auxiliary power, commits the session properties, and leaves the session in the Uncommitted state. This method also performs a hard reset on the instrument and driver software. This method has the same functionality as using reset in Measurement and Automation Explorer. This will also open the output relay on instruments that have an output relay.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeDriverUtility.ResetWithDefaults
member.summary: Resets the instrument to a known state. This method disables power generation, resets session properties to their default values, clears errors such as over-temperature and unexpected loss of auxiliary power, commits the session properties, and leaves the session in the Running state. In addition to exhibiting the behavior of , this method can assign defined default values for configurable properties from the IVI configuration.

This method performs a simple series of tests verifying that the NI-SCOPE instrument is powered on and responding.
This method calls , which resets the software state.

member.summary: Specifies the units of the waveform measurement reference levels. If you choose , then the measurement routine uses to map the percentage values to voltages. By choosing , you can set the voltage threshold values directly and avoid extra calculations.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeMeasurementReferenceLevelUnits.Voltage

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeMeasurementReferenceLevelUnits.Percentage
member.summary: The reference levels are given as a percentage, where the measurements voltage low and voltage high represent 0% and 100%, respectively.

member.summary: The acquisition is complete.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeArrayMeasurementType
member.summary: Specifies various array measurements.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeArrayMeasurementType.NoMeasurement
member.summary: No measurement is applied on the waveform.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeArrayMeasurementType.LastAcquisitionHistogram
member.summary: The initialX value returned is the bin value for the first bin, corresponding to the midpoint of the range of values in the first bin. The xIncrement returned is the bin size.
member.remarks:
Units: Count
X Units: Volts
Resulting Array Size:

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeArrayMeasurementType.FftPhaseSpectrum
member.summary: The phase spectrum is calculated using a split-radix real FFT. If the number of acquired points is not a power of two, zeros are padded at the end of the waveform so it is the next higher power of two. The phase spectrum is unwrapped.
member.remarks:
Units: Radians
X Units: Hertz
Resulting Array Size: Next higher power of two, then inputSize divided by two.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeArrayMeasurementType.FftAmplitudeSpectrumVoltsRms
member.summary: The amplitude spectrum is calculated using a split-radix real FFT. If the number of acquired points is not a power of two, zeros are padded at the end of the waveform so it is the next higher power of two.
member.remarks:
Units: Volts RMS
X Units: Hertz
Resulting Array Size: Next higher power of two, then inputSize divided by two.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeArrayMeasurementType.MultipleAcquisitionVoltageHistogram
member.summary: The initialX value returned is the bin value for the first bin, corresponding to the midpoint of the range of values in the first bin. The xIncrement returned is the bin size.
member.remarks:
Units: Count
X Units: Volts
Resulting Array Size: The value of during the first voltage histogram measurement after the histogram is cleared.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeArrayMeasurementType.MultipleAcquisitionTimeHistogram
member.summary: The initialX value returned is the bin value for the first bin, corresponding to the midpoint of the range of values in the first bin. The xIncrement returned is the bin size.
member.remarks:
Units: Count
X Units: Seconds
Resulting Array Size: The value of during the first time histogram measurement after the histogram is cleared.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeArrayMeasurementType.ArrayIntegral
member.summary:
The waveform is integrated using Simpson's rule, fitting a parabola to every 3 points with the following equation:
y[2i+1] = (waveform[2i] + 4*waveform[2i+1] + waveform[2i+2])*dt/3

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeArrayMeasurementType.Derivative
member.summary:
The differences in the waveform are computed using the formula:
y[i] = (waveform[i + 1] - waveform[i - 1]) / (2 * dt), where dt is the time between two points.
member.remarks:
Units: Volts/Second
X Units: Seconds
Resulting Array Size: inputSize - 2

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeArrayMeasurementType.Inverse
member.summary:
The inverse is computed using the following formula:
y[i] = 1.0 / waveform[i].
If waveform[i] is zero, the inverse is zero.
member.remarks:
Units: 1.0/Volts
X Units: Seconds
Resulting Array Size: inputSize

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeArrayMeasurementType.HanningWindow
member.summary:
A Hanning window is applied to the waveform using the following equation:
y[i] = 0.5 * waveform[i] * [1-cos(w)] where w = (2)i/n and n = waveform size.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeArrayMeasurementType.FlatTopWindow
member.summary:
A Flat Top window is applied to the waveform using the following equation:
y[i] = waveform[i] * (0.2810639 - 0.5208972cos(w)+ 0.1980399cos(2w))
where w = (2)i/n and n is the waveform size.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeArrayMeasurementType.PolynomialInterpolation
member.summary: Polynomial interpolation allows oversampling or undersampling a waveform using any order polynomial set by . For example, an order of 1 corresponds to linear interpolation. The new number of points is determined by the input size multiplied by . The sampling factor can be any number greater than 0.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeArrayMeasurementType.MultiplyChannels
member.summary: Multiplies the waveforms from two channels, where one channel is specified by the parameter to , and the other channel is specified by . Any processing steps registered with are completed for the "other channel" before this measurement is done. The two channels used in this measurement must be different.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeArrayMeasurementType.AddChannels
member.summary: Adds the waveforms from two channels, where one channel is specified by the parameter to , and the other channel is specified by . Any processing steps registered with are completed for the "other channel" before this measurement is done. The two channels used in this measurement must be different.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeArrayMeasurementType.SubtractChannels
member.summary: Subtracts the waveforms from two channels, where one channel is specified by the parameter to , and the other channel is specified by . Any processing steps registered with are completed for the "other channel" before this measurement is done. The two channels used in this measurement must be different.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeArrayMeasurementType.DivideChannels
member.summary: Divides the waveforms from two channels, where one channel is specified by the parameter to and the other channel is specified by . Any processing steps registered with are completed for the "other channel" before this measurement is done. The two channels used in this measurement must be different.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeArrayMeasurementType.MultipleAcquisitionAverage
member.summary: The first time this measurement is called after it is cleared, an array the same size as the input is initialized to the input waveform, and the initialX and xIncrement values are set. Every subsequent call updates and returns the running average array without affecting the size of the array. The average array is cleared by calling with the measurement parameter set to .

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeArrayMeasurementType.ButterworthFilter
member.summary:
The input waveform is filtered with a Butterworth IIR algorithm. The type of the filter is specified by as any of the following values: , , , or .
The order of the filter is specified by . Also, a number of points equal to divided by 100 times the input size are eliminated from the beginning of the filtered waveform so the transient response of the filter does not affect further measurements.
member.remarks:
Units: Volts
X Units: Seconds (nearly linear time delay)
Resulting Array Size: inputSize * (1 - / 100)

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeArrayMeasurementType.ChebyshevFilter
member.summary:
The input waveform is filtered with a Chebyshev IIR algorithm. The type of the filter is specified by as any of the following values: , , , or .
The order of the filter is specified by . Also, a number of points equal to divided by 100 times the input size are eliminated from the beginning of the filtered waveform, so the transient response of the filter does not affect further measurements.
member.remarks:
Units: Volts
X Units: Seconds (nearly linear time delay)
Resulting Array Size: inputSize * (1 - / 100)

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeArrayMeasurementType.FftAmplitudeSpectrumDB
member.summary:
The amplitude spectrum is calculated using a split-radix real FFT. If the number of acquired points is not a power of two, zeros are padded at the end of the waveform so it is the next higher power of two. The FFT is scaled to decibels:
db[i] = 20.0 * log10 (Amplitude[i] / Peak Amplitude)
member.remarks:
Units: Decibels relative to peak
X Units: Hertz
Resulting Array Size: Next higher power of two greater than the inputSize divided by two

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeArrayMeasurementType.HammingWindow
member.summary:
A Hamming window is applied to the waveform using the following equation:
y[i] = x[i] [0.54 - 0.46cos(w)] where w = (2 )i/n and n = the number of elements in x.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeArrayMeasurementType.WindowedFirFilter
member.summary:
FIR filters are well suited for applications that require phase information because the phase response is always linear. This prevents distortion of time-domain filtered data. The transient response of an FIR filter is a fixed number of points, filter taps - 1, which are eliminated in the filtered waveform returned.
Windowed FIR filters use the cutoff frequency as part of the design process, but the cutoff is specified before the windowing operation. For Windowed FIR filters of sufficient taps (more than 10 for a simple lowpass), the cutoff frequency has a magnitude near 0.5 (or 6 dB down). This varies slightly with the order and the window type.
member.remarks:
Units: Volts
X Units: Seconds (linear time delay)
Resulting Array Size: inputSize * ( - 1)
The number of taps in the filter, that is, the number of coefficients in the filter, is given by . This number must be odd for highpass and bandstop filters. The window for the coefficients is set with .

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeArrayMeasurementType.BesselFilter
member.summary:
The input waveform is filtered with a Bessel IIR algorithm. The type of the filter is specified by as any of the following values: , , , or .
The order of the filter is specified by . Also, a number of points equal to divided by 100 times the input size are eliminated from the beginning of the filtered waveform so the transient response of the filter does not affect further measurements.
member.remarks:
Units: Volts
X Units: Seconds (nearly linear time delay)
Resulting Array Size: inputSize * (1 - / 100)

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeArrayMeasurementType.TriangleWindow
member.summary:
A triangular window is applied to the waveform using the following equation:
y[i] = waveform[i] * (1 - |w|) where w = (2i - n)/n and n is the number of elements in the waveform.
member.remarks:
Units: Seconds
X Units: Seconds
Resulting Array Size: inputSize

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeArrayMeasurementType.BlackmanWindow
member.summary:
A Blackman window is applied to the waveform using the following equation:
y[i] = waveform[i] * (0.42659071 - 0.49656062cos(w) + 0.07684867cos(2w)) where w = (2)i/n and n is the number of elements in the waveform.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeArrayMeasurementType.ArrayOffset
member.summary: The scalar value of is added to every point in the waveform.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeArrayMeasurementType.ArrayGain
member.summary: Every point in the waveform is multiplied by the scalar value .
member.remarks:
Units: Volts (if gain is unitless)
X Units: Seconds

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannel.FlexFirAntiAliasFilterType
member.summary: Gets or sets the type of filter needed to achieve desired filtering characteristics.
member.value: Specifies the . The default value for this property is .

remarks.para: The NI 5922 flexible-resolution digitizer uses an onboard FIR lowpass antialias filter. Use this property to select from several types of filters to achieve desired filtering characteristics. For most applications, the default value of this property is recommended. The other available filters are useful for optimizing settling time measurements of step responses.

Settling time values refer to the FIR filter only and do not take into account settling time caused by the analog front end. Refer to the NI PXI/PCI-5922 Specifications in the NI High-Speed Digitizers Help for combined digital and analog settling times.

member.seealso: Mapping the NI-SCOPE .NET API to the NI-SCOPE C API

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannel.DigitalGain
member.summary: Gets or sets the gain on the specified channel in hardware before any onboard signal processing occurs.
member.value: The gain can range from -1.5 to +1.5.
member.remarks:
If an overflow occurs, the data is clipped and the driver returns an error. To eliminate overflows, the digital gain should attenuate the ADC data, that is, ADC data should be set to a value less than 1.
The digital gain circuit can overflow if the following condition is not met:
-1 < Unity Scaled User Data × Pre-Filter Gain < 1 You can also use Digital Gain to complete fine-gain adjustments on the ADC data to compensate for channel or system gain imperfections. These adjustments occur in hardware before the data is stored to memory. These adjustments save an additional processing step that normally occurs in software.
To change the default error reporting caused by OSP overflows, change the attribute.
You can access this property only with high-speed digitizers that support onboard signal processing (OSP), such as the NI 5142. If you open a session with an instrument that does not support OSP and you attempt to access this property, a is thrown.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannel.DigitalOffset
member.summary: Gets or sets the offset on the specified channel in hardware before any onboard signal processing occurs.
member.value: The valid values range from –(Vertical Range × 0.4) to +(Vertical Range × 0.4). The default value is 0.
member.remarks:
The digital offset circuit can overflow if the following condition is not met:
-(Vertical Range/2) <= Channel Data + Digital Offset <= +Vertical Range/2.
If an overflow occurs, the data is clipped and the driver returns an error.
To change the default error reporting caused by OSP overflows, change the property.
You can access this property only with high-speed digitizers that support onboard signal processing (OSP), such as the NI PXI-5142. If you open a session with an instrument that does not support OSP and you attempt to access this property, a is thrown.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannel.OnboardSignalProcessing

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannel.BandpassFilterEnabled

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannel.DitherEnabled
member.summary: Gets or sets whether dither is enabled on the channel.
member.remarks: Using dither can improve the spectral performance of the instrument by reducing the effects of quantization. However, adding dither increases the power level to the ADC, so you may need to either decrease the signal level or increase the vertical range.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeFetchRelativeTo
member.summary: Specifies the position to start fetching within one record.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeFetchRelativeTo.Start
member.summary: Fetches data starting at the first point sampled by the digitizer. For devices that support continuous acquisition, you must fetch relative to or relative to before the trigger occurs. The number of points available when fetching relative to start may be extremely large because there may be an infinite number of pretrigger samples if the trigger never occurs. Furthermore, the pretrigger points are sampled into a circular buffer, so the data at the start may be overwritten. If the data is no longer available for fetching, the fetch method throws an exception.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeFetchRelativeTo.Trigger
member.summary: Starts fetching at the first posttrigger sample, which is useful for fetching a small number of points near the trigger.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeFetchRelativeTo.Pretrigger
member.summary: Fetches data relative to the first pretrigger point requested.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeFetchRelativeTo.Now
member.summary: Starts fetching data at the last sample acquired. Therefore, you must use a negative offset when fetching relative to now. This option is useful for configuring an infinite acquisition (one that never triggers) and occasionally fetching the most recent data.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeFetchRelativeTo.ReadPointer
member.summary: Specifies the read pointer value. When you initiate a new acquisition, the read pointer is set to 0. At this point, fetching relative to the read pointer is equivalent to fetching relative to start. After every fetch, the read pointer is incremented to be the sample after the last sample retrieved. Therefore, you can repeatedly fetch relative to the read pointer for a continuous acquisition program.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeFlexFirAntiAliasFilterType
member.summary: Specifies the type of filter to achieve desired filtering characteristics. The NI 5922 flexible-resolution digitizer uses an onboard FIR lowpass antialias filter.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeFlexFirAntiAliasFilterType.Tap48Standard
member.summary:
This filter is optimized for alias protection and frequency-domain flatness.
Alias protection: ranges from 80 dB to 100 dB depending on sample rate
Settling time: within 14 samples from a 50% vertical trigger point
Cutoff frequency: 0.43 x sample rate
Flatness: ripple ranges from 0.005 dB to 0.120 dB depending on selected sample rate. Refer to the NI PXI/PCI-5922 Specifications for more information.
Rise time: approximately 0.75 / (sample rate)

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeFlexFirAntiAliasFilterType.Tap48Hanning
member.summary:
This filter is optimized for the lowest possible bandwidth for a 48-tap filter and maximizes the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR).
Settling time: within 14 samples from a 50% vertical trigger point
Cutoff frequency: 0.030 x sample rate
Flatness: 0 to -3dB within cutoff frequency
Rise time: 11.6 / (sample rate)

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeFlexFirAntiAliasFilterType.Tap16Hanning
member.summary:
This filter is optimized for the lowest possible bandwidth for a 16-tap filter and maximizes the SNR.
Settling time: 6 samples from a 50% vertical trigger point.
Cutoff frequency: 0.08 x sample rate
Flatness: 0 to -3dB within cutoff frequency
Rise time: 7.7 / (sample rate)

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeFlexFirAntiAliasFilterType.Tap8Hanning
member.summary:
This filter is optimized for the lowest possible bandwidth for an 8-tap filter and maximizes the SNR.
Settling time: 4 samples from a 50% vertical trigger point
Cutoff frequency: 0.15 x sample rate
Flatness: 0 to -3 dB within cutoff frequency
Rise time: 3.9 / (sample rate)

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeMeasurementFilterType

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeOverflowErrorReportingMode.Error

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeOverflowErrorReportingMode.Warning

member.summary: Gets the number of cached objects in the collection, which is equal to the number of channels configured using a single-channel string (e.g., "0" or "1").

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeChannelCollection.Item(System.String)
member.summary:
Gets a object from the collection with the specified name. In Visual C#, this property is the indexer.
If the channel name is a string specifying a list or range of channels (e.g., "0,1,2" or "0-6"), a new is created and returned. The created is not added to the collection.
If the channel name corresponds to only one channel (e.g., "0" or "1") and if the channel has previously been accessed and cached in the collection, the corresponding is returned; otherwise if the specified channel name exists on the instrument, a new object is created, added to the collection, and returned.
member.value: The corresponding to the name of the channel.
member.param: A string specifying the name of a single channel (e.g., "0"), a comma-separated list of channels (e.g., "0,1,2"), or range of channels (e.g., "0-2").

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType
member.summary: Specifies various scalar measurements.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.RiseTime
member.summary:
The time span, in seconds, from when the waveform crosses the low reference level until it crosses the high reference level.
The measurement starts at the left edge of the waveform and finds all low reference level crossings until a high reference level crossing. The final low reference level crossing is used in the calculation. The reference levels are specified by and , and their default values are 10% and 90%.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.FallTime
member.summary:
The time span, in seconds, from when the waveform crosses the high reference level until it crosses the low reference level. The measurement starts at the left edge of the waveform and finds all high reference level crossings until a low reference level crossing. The final high reference level crossing is used in the calculation.
The reference levels are specified by and , and their default values are 10% and 90%.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.Frequency
member.summary: The value, in hertz, is 1.0 divided by the .

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.Period
member.summary: The time, in seconds, between the first and third mid reference level crosspoints in seconds. A hysteresis window is applied when finding crosspoints. The mid reference level is 50% by default and is set with .

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.VoltageRms
member.summary:
The value, in volts RMS, determined by the following equation:
Voltage RMS = sqrt ( ( waveform[i]^2) / numPoints)

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.VoltagePeakToPeak
member.summary: The difference, in volts, of and .

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.VoltageMax
member.summary: The waveform is searched for its maximum point in volts.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.VoltageMin
member.summary: The waveform is searched for the minimum point in volts.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.VoltageHigh
member.summary: The last histogram method is used where the voltage high result is the voltage, in volts, of the histogram bin with the maximum number of hits above 60% of the waveform's voltage peak-to-peak value. This calculation is useful for ignoring the overshoot and preshoot on square waves.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.VoltageLow
member.summary: The last acquisition histogram method is used where the voltage low result, in volts, is the voltage of the histogram bin with the maximum number of hits below 40% of the waveform's voltage peak-to-peak value. This calculation is useful for ignoring the overshoot and preshoot on square waves.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.VoltageAverage
member.summary:
The value, in volts, determined by the following equation:
Voltage Average = waveform[i] / numPoints

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.WidthNegative
member.summary: The time difference, in seconds, between the first two mid reference level crossings, where the slopes are negative and positive, respectively. A digital hysteresis is used when finding the crosspoints.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.WidthPositive
member.summary: The time difference, in seconds, between the first two mid reference level crossings, where the slopes are positive and negative, respectively. A digital hysteresis is used when finding the crosspoints.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.DutyCycleNegative
member.summary: The value, in percentage, is the negative width divided by the 100 times period.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.DutyCyclePositive
member.summary: The value, in percentage, is divided by 100 times .

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.VoltageAmplitude
member.summary: The difference of the and the , in volts.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.VoltageCycleRms
member.summary:
The number of points in a period, in volts RMS, calculated using the equation:
pointsPerPeriod = int (period / dt + 0.5)
where dt is the time between two points and int is a function that returns the integer portion of a floating-point number.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.VoltageCycleAverage
member.summary:
The number of points in a period in volts calculated using the following equation:
pointsPerPeriod = int (period / dt + 0.5)
where dt is the time between two points, and int is a function that returns the integer portion of a floating-point number.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.Overshoot
member.summary:
The measurement is done on the first edge of the waveform. If two edges exist, the algorithm finds the time interval from the first edge until one half the time to the second edge. The local maxima and minima are found in this interval. If only one edge is present in the waveform, the local maximum and minimum are found between the first edge and the end of the waveform.
If the first edge is positive sloped, overshoot = 100 * (local maximum - voltage high) / voltage amplitude.
If the first edge is negative sloped, overshoot = 100 * (voltage low - local minimum) / voltage amplitude.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.Preshoot
member.summary:
The measurement is done on the second edge of the waveform if two edges exist. The algorithm finds the time interval from the middle time between the two edges until the second edge. The local maxima and minima are found in this interval. If only one edge is present in the waveform, the local maximum and minimum are found from the start of the waveform to the first edge.
If the edge is negative sloped, preshoot = 100 * (local maximum - voltage high) / voltage amplitude.
If the edge is positive sloped, preshoot = 100 * (voltage low - local minimum) / voltage amplitude.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.LowReferenceVolts
member.summary: The voltage, in volts, corresponding to the low reference level.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.MidReferenceVolts
member.summary: The voltage, in volts, corresponding to the mid reference level.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.HighReferenceVolts
member.summary: The voltage, in volts, corresponding to the high reference level.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.Area
member.summary: Area = * numPoints * delta time between two points, in volts*seconds.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.CycleArea
member.summary:
Cycle area = voltage cycle average * pointsPerPeriod * dt
where pointsPerPeriod is defined in the description.
Units: Volt * Seconds

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.Integral
member.summary:
Numerical integration is done using Simpson's rule.
Units: Volt * Seconds

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.VoltageBase
member.summary:
If the histogram bin corresponding to voltage low has over 5% of the total hits, the voltage low result is returned. Otherwise, the voltage minimum calculation is returned. This allows using the voltage base to get a reasonable answer for either a square wave (ignoring the overshoot and preshoot) or a triangle wave (where a histogram fails).
Units: Volts

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.VoltageTop
member.summary: If the histogram bin corresponding to has over 5% of the total hits, the voltage high result is returned. Otherwise, the calculation is returned. This allows using the voltage top to get a reasonable answer for either a square wave (ignoring the overshoot and preshoot) or a triangle wave (where a histogram fails).

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.FftFrequency
member.summary:
The FFT amplitude spectrum is calculated using a split-radix real FFT, and the frequency, in hertz, corresponding to the maximum amplitude is returned.
The FFT amplitude spectrum is calculated using a split-radix real FFT, and the frequency corresponding to the maximum amplitude is returned. If the input waveform size is not a power of two, the waveform is zero-padded to the next higher power of two. The frequency resolution is sampling rate / number of points.
The DC bin of the FFT is ignored when searching for the maximum amplitude, so the FFT frequency should ignore any DC offsets. However, the zero-padding used in the FFT measurement can introduce other low-frequency components if the waveform has a large DC offset. To avoid problems, make sure the is a power of 2, so no zero padding occurs. You can fetch this property using the . Alternately, you can use AC coupling on the digitizer to solve the problem.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.FftAmplitude
member.summary: The FFT amplitude spectrum is calculated using a split-radix real FFT, and the maximum amplitude, in volts RMS, is returned. If the input waveform size is not a power of two, the waveform is zero-padded to the next higher power of two.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.RiseSlewRate
member.summary:
The minus the is divided by the calculation.
Units: Volts/second

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.FallSlewRate
member.summary:
The value is minus the is divided by the fall-time calculation. The result is always negative.
Units: Volts/second

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.ACEstimate
member.summary:
The DC estimate is subtracted from the waveform, and a Hanning window is applied to give a processed waveform. The RMS voltage is calculated with the following equation:
sqrt ( [ processed waveform[i]^2] / [numPoints * enbw * cg^2] ),
where the equivalent noise bandwidth (enbw) for the Hanning window is 1.5, and the coherent gain (cg) is 0.5. This algorithm minimizes the effect of an uneven number of waveform cycles in the measurement, which could arbitrarily increase or decrease the RMS value.
Units: Volts RMS

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.DCEstimate
member.summary:
A Hanning window is applied to give a processed waveform and the voltage average is calculated with the following equation:
voltage average = ( processed waveform[i] ) / (cg * numPoints)
where the coherent gain (cg) of the Hanning window is 0.5—the DC gain of the window.
Units: Volts RMS

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.TimeDelay
member.summary:
The algorithm finds the first time that the waveform from the channel specified by the channel parameter crosses its mid reference level. Next, the algorithm finds the first two times that the waveform from the channel crosses its mid reference level. The time delay is the time between two edges with the same slope. The mid reference level is stored on a per channel basis, and mid reference levels do not need to be the same. All reference levels use a digital hysteresis.
Units: seconds

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.AveragePeriod
member.summary: Up to 256 mid reference level crossings are found on the waveform using a digital hysteresis. The time difference between the last crossing and the first crossing is divided by the number of periods found in the waveform. The last crossing is defined as the last crossing in the waveform with the same slope as the first crossing, so an integer number of periods exist in the waveform.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.AverageFrequency
member.summary:
The value is 1.0 divided by the .
Units: Hertz

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.VoltageBaseToTop
member.summary: The value of minus .

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.ScopeScalarMeasurementType.PhaseDelay
member.summary:
The time delay divided by the period, of the waveform on the channel specified by the measurement method, times 360 degrees.
Units: Degrees

member.summary: Configures the digitizer to generate a signal that other instruments can detect when configured for digital triggering or sharing clocks.
member.remarks: specifies what condition causes the digitizer to generate the signal. specifies where to send the signal on the hardware (such as a PFI connector or RTSI line). In cases where multiple instances of a particular signal exist, use the signal identifier input to specify which instance to control. You can call this method multiple times and set each line available to a different signal. To un-program a specific line on an instrument, call this method with the signal you no longer want to export and set output terminal to . You may also use the properties on to export signals.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.NIScope.Close
member.summary:
Performs the following actions after you finish using an instrument driver session:
Closes the instrument I/O session.
Destroys the IVI session and all of its attributes.
Deallocates any memory resources used by the IVI session.
member.seealso: Mapping the NI-SCOPE .NET API to the NI-SCOPE C API

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIScope.NIScope.Dispose
member.summary: Closes the specified session and deallocates the reserved resources, if not already disposed.
member.remarks:
You can call this method safely more than once, even if the session is already closed.
A call to this method disposes the SafeHandle class used to hold the instrument handle. If the call to this method fails for some reason (e.g., the session was closed by some external means) you will not be notified about the failure. To help you identify failures in the ReleaseHandle method of the SafeHandle class, managed debugging assistant (MDA) is activated.
For details refer to .
The call to this method fails when you externally close a session by:
Initializing a session with a resource name for which the session is already open, within the same process. This causes the instrument handle held by the existing session to become invalid.
Getting the instrument handle out using and closing this handle directly.

member.summary: The digitizer DC couples the input signal.

member.summary: The digitizer filters the signal to remove high frequencies.

member.summary: The digitizer filters the signal to remove low frequencies.
